item.title: Visualizing an Atom Part 1: Schrödinger
item.dc:creator: Unit Normal

Continue reading "Visualizing an Atom Part 1: Schrödinger"
item.content:encoded:
This is not a complete course on concepts in quantum mechanics. We assume the audience had at least a semester in undergraduate quantum mechanics. The derivation of the wavefunction(s) along with many core concepts have been left out. There are many sources that develop quantum mechanic more fully than we will. We suggests Introduction to Quantum Mechanics by Griffiths or Modern Quantum Mechanics by Sakurai as starting resources on the subject. We will try to develop basic concepts to understand the visuals presented. The main goal is to visualize the single electron hydrogen atom in the framework of quantum mechanics as described by the Schrödinger equation and Dirac equation.

A non-relativistic electron in a spherical potential, namely the Coulomb potential, can be modeled using the Schrödinger equation

where the probability density of the electron is given by |ψ|2=ψ*ψ. The Hamiltonian above assumes a stationary nucleus of charge Ze. Motion of the nucleus can be introduced by taking the reduced mass, μ=mNme/(mN+me), where mN is the mass of the nucleus, instead of the electron mass, me. We can define the correction factor as M=1/(1+me/mN) and it is clear that M approaches unity for heavy nuclei. For a hydrogen atom, M≈0.99946. For our purposes, it is sufficient to consider a stationary nucleus
relative to the electron motion.

Since the Hamiltonian has spherical symmetry, we choose to work in spherical coordinates. The Schrödinger equation expands to become

The solutions to this differential equation is separable and takes the form of

where Rn,l(r) describes the radial distribution and the spherical harmonics Ylml(θ,ϕ) describes the angular distribution. These functions are defined as

where LαN(x) is the generalized Laguerre polynomial and Plml(x) is the associated Legendre polynomial. a0 is the Bohr radius for an electron in the hydrogen atom. It is useful to note that the only ϕ dependence of the wavefunction ψn,l,ml(r,θ,ϕ) is exp(imlϕ). The consequence of this is the probability density given by |ψn,l,ml(r,θ,ϕ)|2 is independent of ϕ and therefore has cylindrical symmetry. It is enough to view the planar cross-section described by the ρ-z plane where ρ is the radial vector projection onto the azimuthal plane.

The index n,l,ml describe the eigenstate(s) of the Hamiltonian associated with the eigenvalue E. n is
typically referred to as the principal quantum number and uniquely determines the energy level of the atom, i.e. the eigenvalue E is only dependent on n, E → En. Solving for the energy in the Schrödinger equation yields

The principal quantum number takes on any positive integer values, n∈ℤ+. The orbital quantum number l describes the shape of the orbital. This is evident in the fact that both the radial and angular functions depend on l. In fact, there are l angular nodes and n-l-1 radial nodes. Of the l angular nodes, |ml| of the nodes lie in the x-y plane while the remaining l-|ml| nodes lie in the ρ-z plane. Values of l are non-negative integer up to and including n-1, l∈{0,1,…,n-1}. ml is the magnetic quantum number. It determines the shift in energy levels of atomic orbitals in the presence of an external magnetic field. Values of ml are from -l to +l in integer steps, ml∈{-l,-l+1,…,l-1,l}.

The charge of the nucleus does not affect the overall shape of the orbitals. The dependence on the charge, Z, is only in the radial function and energy eigenvalue. This means that the charge only affects how tightly bounded the electron is. The charge, Z, sets the scale size of the orbitals and the binding energy of the state. This is what we would expect given the Coulomb potential.

Electrons are fermions with spin 1/2. The quantum numbers s and ms describe the spin state of the electron. The solution to the Schrödinger equation with a static electric potential does not account for the spin nature of the electron. The energy eigenstates for an electron bound to a nucleus can be extended to include spin by taking

where χms are eigenstates of the spin operator, S2, and the spin projection operator, Sz. For an electron,
ms=±1/2 which corresponds to alignment and anti-alignment with the z-axis, and are the eigenvalues of Sz (the eigenvalues are ±ℏ/2 when using S.I. units). The spin states do not affect the electron probability distribution of pure eigenstates in the Schrödinger model in the absence of an external magnetic field. The inclusion of spin in our model is for the completeness of the quantum state.

The wavefunction are energy eigenstates of the Hamiltonian for an electron in a Coulomb potential with energy eigenvalues given by En. Any normalized linear combinations of these eigenstates are valid solutions to the Hamiltonian and are valid states for the electron.

Spectroscopic Notation

We will denote the eigenstates in spectroscopic notation. The standard notation for state is

where s is the total spin momentum, L is the total orbital angular momentum, j is the total angular momentum. Since we’re looking at a single electron, s=1/2, in state ψn,l,ml , we will use a slightly modified (and nonstandard) notation where we denote ml,ms instead of j.

The letter L is given by the mapping

with l≥4 continuing alphabetically, only skipping J, i.e. l=7 corresponds to K.

Later on, we will work in the total angular momentum basis and we will modify the standard notation by including mj to denote the state given by ψn,l,j,mj .

All the orbitals for n=1 to n=7. We removed the ms index as it was irrelevant to the orbital shape.
